qas.question: Who introduced a system of musical notation used in the Balkans in the 14th century?
What was the name of the new musical style introduced in the Late Middle Ages?
Which musical style did ars nova replace in the 14th century?
Who were the leading composers of the trecento period?

answers.text: Giovanni da Cascia, Jacopo da Bologna and Francesco Landini

qas.question: Kukuzelis reformed the music of which religion?
Who introduced a system of nonmusical notation used in the Balkans in the 14th century?
What was the name of the old musical style introduced in the Late Middle Ages?
Which musical style did ars nova replace in the 13th century?

plausible_answers.text: Giovanni da Cascia, Jacopo da Bologna and Francesco Landini

qas.question: Who were the nonleading composers of the trecento period?
Kukuzelis kept the music of which religion?

context: The main representatives of the new style, often referred to as <a1_0><b6_0>ars nova<b6_0/><a1_0/> as opposed to the <a2_0><b7_0>ars antiqua<b7_0/><a2_0/>, were the composers Philippe de Vitry and Guillaume de Machaut. In Italy, where the Provençal troubadours had also found refuge, the corresponding period goes under the name of trecento, and the leading composers were <a3_0><b8_0>Giovanni da Cascia, Jacopo da Bologna and Francesco Landini<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Prominent reformer of <a4_0><b9_0>Orthodox Church<b9_0/><a4_0/> music from the first half of 14th century was <a0_0><b5_0>John Kukuzelis<b5_0/><a0_0/>; he also introduced a system of notation widely used in the Balkans in the following centuries.
